docs.lead_paragraph: It is traditional for relievers with the least service time on a team to stock and handle the bullpen bag. What makes Boston’s Hideki Okajima different is that he pitched 11 seasons in Japan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Devern Hansack. Remember the name. Remember it because it is the name of a pitcher who pitched a no-hitter that most everyone probably doesn't know about. A long rain delay preceded the game Hansack pitched on the last day of last season, and rain shortened it. Hansack, in his second major league start, pitched himself onto Page 369 of the Elias record book, ''no-hit games fewer than nine innings,'' adding his name for this year's edition after Pascual Pérez, Montreal vs. Philadelphia, 1988.

docs.lead_paragraph: Red Sox reliever Keith Foulke, who closed out the 2004 World Series, said he might retire after this season. Foulke, who turns 34 next month and has an option for next season, has been bothered by elbow tendinitis and a bad back. ''I have to see if I still have the motivation to train and be one of the better pitchers in the league,'' he said. ''I want to be the pitcher I was before that and my body went south on me.'' MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT (NYT)
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox pitcher Keith Foulke says he may retire after this season (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jeff Reardon, who pitched for the Mets and the Yankees and was one of the top relief pitchers in baseball, was charged Monday with robbing a local jewelry store. Reardon, 50, was released on $5,000 bond from the Palm Beach County Jail on Tuesday, after a judge ruled that he could be put under house arrest without monitoring, provided that he sought a mental-health evaluation within seven days.
docs.abstract: Former Boston Red Sox pitcher Jeff Reardon is arrested for robbing jewelry store in Palm Beach County (Fla); photos (M)

headline.main: Former Top Reliever Is Arrested on Robbery Charges

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Boy Wonder is back. Well, not quite, but almost. Word was swirling around Fenway Park yesterday that Theo Epstein, a Boston hero for the team's 2004 World Series victory, will soon return to the Red Sox' front office as an adviser to the baseball operations department. Larry Lucchino, the team's chief executive, said the club would have a ''press event this week to talk about the restructuring of our front office.''
docs.abstract: Murray Chass On Baseball column discusses rumor that former Boston Red Sox general manager Theo Epstein could return as adviser (M)2
docs.snippet: Word was swirling around Fenway Park that Theo Epstein will soon return to the Red Sox' front office as an adviser to the baseball operations department....

headline.main: Epstein May Return to Red Sox

docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT do you say when the front office sends you a pitcher four days before the end of the season? Thank you, or what took you so long? Terry Francona, the Red Sox' manager, preferred to avoid the subject altogether yesterday afternoon as heavy rain blew out of town and the ubiquitous Mike Stanton rode a late September trade wind in from Washington, giving them another situational left-hander -- for four days, anyway, at the cost of two low-level minor league pitchers and the appearance of being a team still doing its homework the day before the start of final exams.
docs.snippet: The Red Sox are alive. They have a chance. Their fans can still dream of miracles, circa 2004. For that, Terry Francona deserves an award....

docs.lead_paragraph: JOHN OLERUD will not take credit for the Red Sox' 27-hit outburst yesterday. Those things happen, especially with good teams that are way overdue. Understated, maybe even underrated, Olerud does tend to stabilize teams. He has done it twice in New York, and now he may do it for Boston.
docs.snippet: John Olerud drilled three hits and twice smacked the ball off the pitcher's body for outs in his first game with the Red Sox....

headline.main: Olerud's Skill Is Noticeable Even During A Laugher
